bbc news -pipe- entertainment -pipe- cleese ' retires from performing ' home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk business health science & environment technology entertainment arts & culture also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 07:40 gmt 08:40 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version cleese ' retires from performing ' cleese was branded a comedy genius for his role as basil fawlty comedy legend john cleese has said he is retiring from writing and performing sitcoms because he will never manage to top the success of fawlty towers .
the monty python star will concentrate instead on publishing a book on the history of comedy and will hold classes explaining how to make people laugh .
the 66-year-old told the times he would be a " comedy professor " to " teach young talent some rules of the game " .
he said too much tv comedy was poorly written and aimed at us teenagers .
the monty python star criticised modern performers who are n't aware of the " basic principles " of comedy .
" it is very rare today to see someone with that grasp of old-fashioned comedy , " he said .
" the last truly excellent performance i saw was eddie izzard .
but ricky gervais is also a match for the great american sitcoms . "
comedy great cleese started his comedy career with the footlights team while studying law at cambridge university .
monty python gave cleese the chance to play around with comedy he soon became a regular performer on the bbc , appearing on shows such as i 'm sorry i 'll read that again and the frost report .
when the innovative comedy series monty python 's flying circus hit the screens in 1969 , cleese was perhaps the most recognisable face in the team .
more recently , the comedian has appeared as gadget-master q in the james bond films , and as the voice of king harold in the animation shrek 2 .
he has also co-written the script for the next film by wallace and gromit creators aardman animations .
cleese 's last major work for the bbc was the 2001 documentary series the human face , which combined comic sketches with popular science to explore identity , beauty , fame and expressions .
but the comedian said the experience had been a " total nightmare " and accused the bbc of needless interference , chaotic management and misspent budgets .
his current project is a world cup single based on basil fawlty 's famous exclamation , " do n't mention the war " .
e-mail this to a friend printable version see also cleese 's contribution to comedy 12 jun 06 -pipe- entertainment fawlty towers flying high at 30 19 sep 05 -pipe- entertainment john cleese writing aardman film 12 may 05 -pipe- entertainment cleese lashes out at bbc 28 feb 01 -pipe- entertainment us drops cleese sitcom 09 apr 02 -pipe- entertainment the birth of python 01 oct 99 -pipe- monty python and now for something completely different ? 01 oct 99 -pipe- monty python related bbc links comedy guide - john cleese comedy guide - fawlty towers comedy guide - monty python related internet links do n't mention the war the bbc is not responsible for the content of external internet sites top entertainment stories u2 reschedule us and canada dates cheryl ' on the mend ' says simon cowell zsa zsa gabor taken to hospital most popular stories now most shared most read living life in augmented reality most popular now , in detail most shared most read model ' said taylor sent diamond ' germany closes 9/11 plot mosque apple iphone boss leaves company bbc loses gadgets worth £ 240,000 naked rollercoaster ' record ' set moscow deaths double in heatwave eurosceptic swiss count their blessings turkey groom kills wedding guests israel ship raid ' legal ' says pm n korea ' fires shells into sea ' most popular now , in detail features , views , analysis planning an exit attacks by afghan soldiers pose nato problems sanction evasion ?
how iran has been registering ships in the isle of man cultural pride taiwan 's efforts to revive indigenous languages most popular now most popular now -pipe- 77,257 people are reading stories on the site right now . " ; products & services e-mail news mobiles alerts news feeds podcasts bbc copyright notice mmx most popular now -pipe- 27,886 pages were read in the last minute . " ; back to top ^ ^ help privacy and cookies policy news sources about the bbc contact us

he has also co-written the script for the next film by wallace and gromit creators aardman animations .
cleese 's last major work for the bbc was the 2001 documentary series the human face , which combined comic sketches with popular science to explore identity , beauty , fame and expressions .
but the comedian said the experience had been a " total nightmare " and accused the bbc of needless interference , chaotic management and misspent budgets .
his current project is a world cup single based on basil fawlty 's famous exclamation , " do n't mention the war " .
e-mail this to a friend printable version see also cleese 's contribution to comedy 12 jun 06 -pipe- entertainment fawlty towers flying high at 30 19 sep 05 -pipe- entertainment john cleese writing aardman film 12 may 05 -pipe- entertainment cleese lashes out at bbc 28 feb 01 -pipe- entertainment us drops cleese sitcom 09 apr 02 -pipe- entertainment the birth of python 01 oct 99 -pipe- monty python and now for something completely different ? 01 oct 99 -pipe- monty python related bbc links comedy guide - john cleese comedy guide - fawlty towers comedy guide - monty python related internet links do n't mention the war the bbc is not responsible for the content of external internet sites top entertainment stories u2 reschedule us and canada dates cheryl ' on the mend ' says simon cowell zsa zsa gabor taken to hospital most popular stories now most shared most read enola gay navigator has ' no regrets ' the battle for berlin 's gardens china country profile most popular now , in detail most shared most read turkey groom kills wedding guests robbie williams weds ayda field world sauna event finalist dies north korea ' holds southern boat ' duchess tries to avoid bankruptcy iran lawyer in norway asylum bid couple murdered on pakistan trip the battle for berlin 's gardens pakistan hit by deadly landslips computer boss quits in sex probe most popular now , in detail features , views , analysis planning an exit attacks by afghan soldiers pose nato problems sanction evasion ?

bbc news -pipe- entertainment -pipe- curtain rises on new tosca opera home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk business health science & environment technology entertainment arts & culture also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 07:52 gmt 08:52 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version curtain rises on new tosca opera by neil smith entertainment reporter , bbc news the royal opera house in london is mounting a new production of tosca for the first time in 40 years .
star angela gheorghiu and director jonathan kent explain why the time is right to re-evaluate puccini 's classic .
maria callas ' portrayal of tosca has become legendary for four decades , franco zeffirelli 's production of tosca was a mainstay of the royal opera house repertoire .
first presented in 1964 with maria callas as tosca and tito gobbi as police chief scarpia , it returned to covent garden year on year and was staged more than 240 times .
in 2004 , however , the decision was made to retire this long-running staple and commission a new version .
it is a move that makes sense to jonathan kent , the british director chosen to re-appraise giacomo puccini 's 1900 masterpiece for a 21st century audience .
" each generation has to reinvent these classics or they become museum pieces , " he told the bbc news website .
" because it was callas coming together with zeffirelli and gobbi , it 's one of those productions people who were n't even born get misty-eyed over .
" but i think 40 years is too long , no matter how great it was . "
' taut melodrama ' kent , formerly the joint artistic director of london 's almeida theatre , has a strong background in drama but is a relative newcomer to opera .
however , he believes tosca - which puccini adapted from a five-act french play - is an ideal vehicle for his talents .
" what i admire about it , quite apart from the thrilling music , is its theatre craft , " he said .
romanian soprano gheorghiu plays puccini 's heroine in the new tosca " it 's a taut , sinewy melodrama , exquisitely put together .
there is n't an ounce of flesh on it .
" puccini stripped the play down until it was an unstoppable arrow .
" that 's what interested me : to find a way within that hurtling narrative to examine the relationships and its themes of sex , power and death . "
set in 1800 rome , tosca tells of a celebrated opera singer whose determination to save her lover 's life leads her into a deadly imbroglio with the chief of police , baron scarpia .
in the first of the production 's two casts , tosca and scarpia are played by romanian soprano angela gheorghiu and welsh bass-baritone bryn terfel .
gheorghiu previously played tosca in a 2001 film but has yet to perform the entire role on stage .
surprisingly , she says it was harder to portray the character on screen than in the flesh .
climactic plummet " it 's much more difficult on camera , " the 40-year-old opera star told the bbc news website .
" this is one night , but on film it was every day for two months .
" it was hard to be there all the time - there was no way to escape .
i got tired . "
gheorghiu appears in six performances of the 12-night run with us soprano catherine naglestad stepping in for the remaining performances .
welsh opera star terfel portrays the villainous baron scarpia but the ghost of callas does not haunt the romanian singer , especially as she found her predecessor 's portrayal wanting in some departments .
" to my taste she did n't understand the role , " she explains in slightly fractured but highly expressive english .
" i think she was all the time furious , hysterical .
" i want to be much more feminine and have moments when i make decisions and have power . "
if there is one aspect that gives her pause , it is tosca 's climactic plummet from the battlements of the castel sant 'angelo .
" i never done the jumping !
that 's the only thing i did n't rehearse , " says gheorghiu .
" i have a list of people who want to catch me . "
rather that than the trampoline used in one chicago production , which - or so the story goes - saw tosca re-appear from behind the castle walls .
tosca runs at the royal opera house from 13 june to 8 july .
e-mail this to a friend printable version see also callas ' stage jewels go on show 14 sep 05 -pipe- entertainment uk honour for director zeffirelli 24 nov 04 -pipe- entertainment swansong for opera 's 40-year run 18 jul 04 -pipe- entertainment tenors toast tosca 14 jan 00 -pipe- entertainment related bbc links tosca film review classical music h2g2 - opera related internet links royal opera house the bbc is not responsible for the content of external internet sites top entertainment stories u2 reschedule us and canada dates cheryl ' on the mend ' says simon cowell zsa zsa gabor taken to hospital most popular stories now most shared most read nigeria country profile most popular now , in detail most shared most read renault warns of threat to assets swedish bird deaths are explained uk 's ivory coast envoy ' expelled ' global spam levels suddenly fall pentagon budget to get $ 78bn cut banks to pay billions in bonuses hackers uncover secret ps3 keys china stealth plane ' years away ' china ponders parents ' visit law contamination shuts german farms most popular now , in detail features , views , analysis praying for revenge widowed governor in philippines seeks curse plastic fantastic the loyalty reward programme for facebook fans path to the presidency could sarah palin win the republican nomination ?

" but i think 40 years is too long , no matter how great it was . "

however , he believes tosca - which puccini adapted from a five-act french play - is an ideal vehicle for his talents .

romanian soprano gheorghiu plays puccini 's heroine in the new tosca " it 's a taut , sinewy melodrama , exquisitely put together .
there is n't an ounce of flesh on it .
" puccini stripped the play down until it was an unstoppable arrow .

in the first of the production 's two casts , tosca and scarpia are played by romanian soprano angela gheorghiu and welsh bass-baritone bryn terfel .

surprisingly , she says it was harder to portray the character on screen than in the flesh .
climactic plummet " it 's much more difficult on camera , " the 40-year-old opera star told the bbc news website .
" this is one night , but on film it was every day for two months .
" it was hard to be there all the time - there was no way to escape .
i got tired . "
gheorghiu appears in six performances of the 12-night run with us soprano catherine naglestad stepping in for the remaining performances .
welsh opera star terfel portrays the villainous baron scarpia but the ghost of callas does not haunt the romanian singer , especially as she found her predecessor 's portrayal wanting in some departments .
" to my taste she did n't understand the role , " she explains in slightly fractured but highly expressive english .
" i think she was all the time furious , hysterical .
" i want to be much more feminine and have moments when i make decisions and have power . "
if there is one aspect that gives her pause , it is tosca 's climactic plummet from the battlements of the castel sant 'angelo .
" i never done the jumping !
that 's the only thing i did n't rehearse , " says gheorghiu .
" i have a list of people who want to catch me . "
rather that than the trampoline used in one chicago production , which - or so the story goes - saw tosca re-appear from behind the castle walls .
tosca runs at the royal opera house from 13 june to 8 july .

" i have a list of people who want to catch me . "
rather that than the trampoline used in one chicago production , which - or so the story goes - saw tosca re-appear from behind the castle walls .

however , he believes tosca - which puccini adapted from a five-act french play - is an ideal vehicle for his talents .
" what i admire about it , quite apart from the thrilling music , is its theatre craft , " he said .
romanian soprano gheorghiu plays puccini 's heroine in the new tosca " it 's a taut , sinewy melodrama , exquisitely put together .
there is n't an ounce of flesh on it .
" puccini stripped the play down until it was an unstoppable arrow .
" that 's what interested me : to find a way within that hurtling narrative to examine the relationships and its themes of sex , power and death . "

surprisingly , she says it was harder to portray the character on screen than in the flesh .
climactic plummet " it 's much more difficult on camera , " the 40-year-old opera star told the bbc news website .
" this is one night , but on film it was every day for two months .
" it was hard to be there all the time - there was no way to escape .
i got tired . "

welsh opera star terfel portrays the villainous baron scarpia but the ghost of callas does not haunt the romanian singer , especially as she found her predecessor 's portrayal wanting in some departments .
" to my taste she did n't understand the role , " she explains in slightly fractured but highly expressive english .
" i think she was all the time furious , hysterical .
" i want to be much more feminine and have moments when i make decisions and have power . "
if there is one aspect that gives her pause , it is tosca 's climactic plummet from the battlements of the castel sant 'angelo .
" i never done the jumping !
that 's the only thing i did n't rehearse , " says gheorghiu .
" i have a list of people who want to catch me . "
rather that than the trampoline used in one chicago production , which - or so the story goes - saw tosca re-appear from behind the castle walls .
tosca runs at the royal opera house from 13 june to 8 july .

rather that than the trampoline used in one chicago production , which - or so the story goes - saw tosca re-appear from behind the castle walls .
tosca runs at the royal opera house from 13 june to 8 july .

bbc news -pipe- entertainment -pipe- curtain rises on new tosca opera home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk business health science & environment technology entertainment arts & culture also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 07:52 gmt 08:52 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version curtain rises on new tosca opera by neil smith entertainment reporter , bbc news the royal opera house in london is mounting a new production of tosca for the first time in 40 years .
star angela gheorghiu and director jonathan kent explain why the time is right to re-evaluate puccini 's classic .
maria callas ' portrayal of tosca has become legendary for four decades , franco zeffirelli 's production of tosca was a mainstay of the royal opera house repertoire .
first presented in 1964 with maria callas as tosca and tito gobbi as police chief scarpia , it returned to covent garden year on year and was staged more than 240 times .
in 2004 , however , the decision was made to retire this long-running staple and commission a new version .
it is a move that makes sense to jonathan kent , the british director chosen to re-appraise giacomo puccini 's 1900 masterpiece for a 21st century audience .
" each generation has to reinvent these classics or they become museum pieces , " he told the bbc news website .
" because it was callas coming together with zeffirelli and gobbi , it 's one of those productions people who were n't even born get misty-eyed over .
" but i think 40 years is too long , no matter how great it was . "
' taut melodrama ' kent , formerly the joint artistic director of london 's almeida theatre , has a strong background in drama but is a relative newcomer to opera .
however , he believes tosca - which puccini adapted from a five-act french play - is an ideal vehicle for his talents .
" what i admire about it , quite apart from the thrilling music , is its theatre craft , " he said .
romanian soprano gheorghiu plays puccini 's heroine in the new tosca " it 's a taut , sinewy melodrama , exquisitely put together .
there is n't an ounce of flesh on it .
" puccini stripped the play down until it was an unstoppable arrow .
" that 's what interested me : to find a way within that hurtling narrative to examine the relationships and its themes of sex , power and death . "
set in 1800 rome , tosca tells of a celebrated opera singer whose determination to save her lover 's life leads her into a deadly imbroglio with the chief of police , baron scarpia .
in the first of the production 's two casts , tosca and scarpia are played by romanian soprano angela gheorghiu and welsh bass-baritone bryn terfel .
gheorghiu previously played tosca in a 2001 film but has yet to perform the entire role on stage .
surprisingly , she says it was harder to portray the character on screen than in the flesh .
climactic plummet " it 's much more difficult on camera , " the 40-year-old opera star told the bbc news website .
" this is one night , but on film it was every day for two months .
" it was hard to be there all the time - there was no way to escape .
i got tired . "
gheorghiu appears in six performances of the 12-night run with us soprano catherine naglestad stepping in for the remaining performances .
welsh opera star terfel portrays the villainous baron scarpia but the ghost of callas does not haunt the romanian singer , especially as she found her predecessor 's portrayal wanting in some departments .
" to my taste she did n't understand the role , " she explains in slightly fractured but highly expressive english .
" i think she was all the time furious , hysterical .
" i want to be much more feminine and have moments when i make decisions and have power . "
if there is one aspect that gives her pause , it is tosca 's climactic plummet from the battlements of the castel sant 'angelo .
" i never done the jumping !
that 's the only thing i did n't rehearse , " says gheorghiu .
" i have a list of people who want to catch me . "
rather that than the trampoline used in one chicago production , which - or so the story goes - saw tosca re-appear from behind the castle walls .
tosca runs at the royal opera house from 13 june to 8 july .

" i never done the jumping !
that 's the only thing i did n't rehearse , " says gheorghiu .
" i have a list of people who want to catch me . "
rather that than the trampoline used in one chicago production , which - or so the story goes - saw tosca re-appear from behind the castle walls .
tosca runs at the royal opera house from 13 june to 8 july .

bbc news -pipe- uk -pipe- england -pipe- cornwall -pipe- hospital holds crutches amnesty home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk england northern ireland scotland wales education magazine uk election business health science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 08:02 gmt 09:02 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version hospital holds crutches amnesty medical aids can be returned to any hospital or health centre people are being asked to return any crutches , walking frames and wheelchairs they may have been given by the royal cornwall hospitals trust .
the medical equipment is handed out to patients by the accident and emergency departments in penzance and truro but sometimes it is not returned .
this has led to fears of serious problems if there is a surge in demand , and it is expensive to keep replacing .
a nurse manager said borrowed crutches can turn up in a number of odd places .
lorraine rogers said : " they 've been seen propping open garage doors and holding up plants in the gardens .
" people will use them for all sorts of things . "
people who have been given crutches , walking sticks or other medical aids , are being asked to check their cupboards and garages and return them to their nearest hospital or health centre .

bbc news -pipe- uk -pipe- england -pipe- cornwall -pipe- hospital holds crutches amnesty home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk england northern ireland scotland wales uk politics education magazine business health science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 08:02 gmt 09:02 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version hospital holds crutches amnesty medical aids can be returned to any hospital or health centre people are being asked to return any crutches , walking frames and wheelchairs they may have been given by the royal cornwall hospitals trust .
the medical equipment is handed out to patients by the accident and emergency departments in penzance and truro but sometimes it is not returned .
this has led to fears of serious problems if there is a surge in demand , and it is expensive to keep replacing .
a nurse manager said borrowed crutches can turn up in a number of odd places .
lorraine rogers said : " they 've been seen propping open garage doors and holding up plants in the gardens .
" people will use them for all sorts of things . "
people who have been given crutches , walking sticks or other medical aids , are being asked to check their cupboards and garages and return them to their nearest hospital or health centre .

bbc news -pipe- uk -pipe- england -pipe- nottinghamshire -pipe- night patrols to make taxis safer home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk england northern ireland scotland wales education magazine uk election business health science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 08:04 gmt 09:04 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version night patrols to make taxis safer the inspectors will work mostly in the evenings and at night nottingham city council is clamping down on illegal taxis by introducing a night-time patrol to make sure cabs are roadworthy and properly licensed .
the uniformed enforcement team will ask for drivers ' licences and insurance as part of the checks .
the first two officers are former taxi drivers - and although they will be based in the city - they will also be making spot checks elsewhere .
nottingham has more than 2,100 licensed taxi drivers .
jim mortell , taxi licensing team leader at nottingham city council , said : " the new uniformed officers are an overt presence on the streets , acting as a visible deterrent to taxi drivers who should not be touting for trade in the city . "
the council is recruiting more officers in a bid to deter illegal out-of-town operators .

bbc news -pipe- uk -pipe- england -pipe- nottinghamshire -pipe- night patrols to make taxis safer home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk england northern ireland scotland wales uk politics education magazine business health science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 08:04 gmt 09:04 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version night patrols to make taxis safer the inspectors will work mostly in the evenings and at night nottingham city council is clamping down on illegal taxis by introducing a night-time patrol to make sure cabs are roadworthy and properly licensed .
the uniformed enforcement team will ask for drivers ' licences and insurance as part of the checks .
the first two officers are former taxi drivers - and although they will be based in the city - they will also be making spot checks elsewhere .
nottingham has more than 2,100 licensed taxi drivers .
jim mortell , taxi licensing team leader at nottingham city council , said : " the new uniformed officers are an overt presence on the streets , acting as a visible deterrent to taxi drivers who should not be touting for trade in the city . "
the council is recruiting more officers in a bid to deter illegal out-of-town operators .

<p>
bbc news -pipe- south asia -pipe- child labour - india 's ' cheap commodity ' bbc news / south asia graphics version bbc sport home news front page -pipe- africa -pipe- americas -pipe- asia-pacific -pipe- europe -pipe- middle east -pipe- south asia -pipe- uk -pipe- business -pipe- health -pipe- science & environment -pipe- technology -pipe- entertainment -pipe- also in the news -pipe- have your say -pipe- tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 08:08 gmt 09:08 uk child labour - india 's ' cheap commodity ' by navdip dhariwal bbc news , tamil nadu farm workers toil long hours in the fields in the indian state of tamil nadu for little reward in the intense heat .
but it is often their only means of survival .
cheap labour is one commodity india has in abundance .
hidden from public view though , is another workforce .
in an isolated spot , miles from the nearest town , is a thriving matchstick industry .
here inside makeshift straw huts - and in the small dwellings that neighbour them - we found some of india 's youngest workers .
rows of exhausted young girls - up to 20 and as young as five are working alongside their mothers .
for 16 hours a day their tiny blistered fingers skilfully turn out matches for export .
ordered to leave the toxic smell of sulphur is overwhelming in the windowless room .
child labour 2006 218m aged 5-17 in work 126m in hazardous work almost 50m work in africa 122m work in asia 70 % of workers in agriculture estimated cost of ending child labour : $ 760m over 20 years source : international labour organisation most computers will open pdf documents automatically , but you may need to download adobe acrobat reader twelve-year-old sindhu dips the tips of the sticks into hot sulphur .
" i start work early but do n't finish until late into the night .
i get paid less than two dollars a week . "
our presence was clearly not welcome .
as we were speaking to the girls the owner came in and ordered us to leave .
within walking distance are other factories .
but again , when we arrived , the youngest workers were quickly led away .
while the factory owner denied he was employing underage workers , almost every single household in this part of tamil nadu has one or more children working long hours in appalling conditions .
campaigners say over 11 million children are forced to work in india .
lighting a fire for a rare family meal , sarojama gathers her five grandchildren around her .
exploited she has barely been able to feed them , so she was forced to borrow money from a local factory owner .
unable to pay back the loan she sent her young grand-daughter to work .
parimeeta was taken out of school and has been working 12 hour days for two years .
the debt is less than $ 20 .
campaigners fear that as india 's economy continues to boom , children are increasingly being exploited to meet the country 's hunger for global success .
in a recent raid in the capital delhi , police rescued a large number of boys from local sweatshops .
agents had lured them from india 's poorest regions , promising the children that they would be taken care of and paid well .
they were found hidden on the top floors of garment factories - held captive in filthy cramped rooms under lock and key .
they painstakingly spent hours applying crystals to garments .
many of the clothes end up being sold in shops in the uk .
ineffective these are places the authorities say are difficult to close down .
but swami agnivesh of the bonded liberation front says that hundreds of children are kept hidden from public view in the buildings of crammed alleyways .
" they are kept in the most appalling conditions and not enough is being done to help them , " he said .
india has laws in place to protect children and bans the use of young workers , but they remain pretty ineffective .
the united nations children 's ' fund says that the sheer volume of children engaged in work is living proof of the world 's failure to protect them .
that is the reason why the agency 's work is focused on building a protective environment which safeguards children from exploitation and abuse .
in tamil nadu local charities have helped pay off families ' debts so that at least some children can be released from the matchstick factories .
finally freed from the shackles of work , they now have some hope of reliving their childhood .
bu it is often a dream that is short-lived .
charity workers admit most of the children are likely to find themselves forced back into a life of bondage .
e-mail this to a friend related to this story : congo 's child miner shame -lrb- 12 jun 06 -pipe- africa -rrb- child workers refuse to quit jobs -lrb- 22 nov 05 -pipe- south asia -rrb- educating india 's child labourers -lrb- 13 sep 05 -pipe- south asia -rrb- misery of india 's child sari weavers -lrb- 29 aug 05 -pipe- south asia -rrb- ' child labourers ' freed in mumbai -lrb- 01 jun 05 -pipe- south asia -rrb- spartacus returns to fight child slavery -lrb- 30 apr 04 -pipe- south asia -rrb- related internet links bbc 's children 's rights homepage united nations children 's fund child rights information network ilo - child labour programme the bbc is not responsible for the content of external internet sites search bbc news : news front page -pipe- africa -pipe- americas -pipe- asia-pacific -pipe- europe -pipe- middle east -pipe- south asia -pipe- uk -pipe- business -pipe- health -pipe- science & environment -pipe- technology -pipe- entertainment -pipe- also in the news -pipe- have your say -pipe- newswatch -pipe- notes -pipe- contact us -pipe- about bbc news -pipe- profiles -pipe- history ^ back to top -pipe- bbc sport home -pipe- bbc homepage -pipe- contact us -pipe- help -pipe- ©
<p>

charity workers admit most of the children are likely to find themselves forced back into a life of bondage .

as we were speaking to the girls the owner came in and ordered us to leave .
within walking distance are other factories .
but again , when we arrived , the youngest workers were quickly led away .
while the factory owner denied he was employing underage workers , almost every single household in this part of tamil nadu has one or more children working long hours in appalling conditions .
campaigners say over 11 million children are forced to work in india .
lighting a fire for a rare family meal , sarojama gathers her five grandchildren around her .
exploited she has barely been able to feed them , so she was forced to borrow money from a local factory owner .
campaigners say over 11 million children work in india unable to pay back the loan she sent her young grand-daughter to work .
parimeeta was taken out of school and has been working 12 hour days for two years .
the debt is less than $ 20 .
campaigners fear that as india 's economy continues to boom , children are increasingly being exploited to meet the country 's hunger for global success .
in a recent raid in the capital delhi , police rescued a large number of boys from local sweatshops .
agents had lured them from india 's poorest regions , promising the children that they would be taken care of and paid well .
they were found hidden on the top floors of garment factories - held captive in filthy cramped rooms under lock and key .
they painstakingly spent hours applying crystals to garments .
many of the clothes end up being sold in shops in the uk .
ineffective these are places the authorities say are difficult to close down .
but swami agnivesh of the bonded liberation front says that hundreds of children are kept hidden from public view in the buildings of crammed alleyways .
" they are kept in the most appalling conditions and not enough is being done to help them , " he said .
india has laws in place to protect children and bans the use of young workers , but they remain pretty ineffective .
the united nations children 's ' fund says that the sheer volume of children engaged in work is living proof of the world 's failure to protect them .
that is the reason why the agency 's work is focused on building a protective environment which safeguards children from exploitation and abuse .
in tamil nadu local charities have helped pay off families ' debts so that at least some children can be released from the matchstick factories .
finally freed from the shackles of work , they now have some hope of reliving their childhood .
bu it is often a dream that is short-lived .
charity workers admit most of the children are likely to find themselves forced back into a life of bondage .

bbc news -pipe- south asia -pipe- child labour - india 's ' cheap commodity ' home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk business health science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog languages urdu hindi bengali pashto nepali tamil sinhala more last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 08:08 gmt 09:08 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version child labour - india 's ' cheap commodity ' by navdip dhariwal bbc news , tamil nadu campaigners say that many children work in appalling conditions enlarge image farm workers toil long hours in the fields in the indian state of tamil nadu for little reward in the intense heat .
but it is often their only means of survival .
cheap labour is one commodity india has in abundance .
hidden from public view though , is another workforce .
in an isolated spot , miles from the nearest town , is a thriving matchstick industry .
here inside makeshift straw huts - and in the small dwellings that neighbour them - we found some of india 's youngest workers .
rows of exhausted young girls - up to 20 and as young as five are working alongside their mothers .
for 16 hours a day their tiny blistered fingers skilfully turn out matches for export .
ordered to leave the toxic smell of sulphur is overwhelming in the windowless room .
child labour 2006 218m aged 5-17 in work 126m in hazardous work almost 50m work in africa 122m work in asia 70 % of workers in agriculture estimated cost of ending child labour : $ 760m over 20 years source : international labour organisation read the full ilo report -lrb- 1.1mb -rrb- most computers will open pdf documents automatically , but you may need to download adobe acrobat reader download the reader here twelve-year-old sindhu dips the tips of the sticks into hot sulphur .
" i start work early but do n't finish until late into the night .
i get paid less than two dollars a week . "
our presence was clearly not welcome .
as we were speaking to the girls the owner came in and ordered us to leave .
within walking distance are other factories .
but again , when we arrived , the youngest workers were quickly led away .
while the factory owner denied he was employing underage workers , almost every single household in this part of tamil nadu has one or more children working long hours in appalling conditions .
campaigners say over 11 million children are forced to work in india .
lighting a fire for a rare family meal , sarojama gathers her five grandchildren around her .
exploited she has barely been able to feed them , so she was forced to borrow money from a local factory owner .
campaigners say over 11 million children work in india unable to pay back the loan she sent her young grand-daughter to work .
parimeeta was taken out of school and has been working 12 hour days for two years .
the debt is less than $ 20 .
campaigners fear that as india 's economy continues to boom , children are increasingly being exploited to meet the country 's hunger for global success .
in a recent raid in the capital delhi , police rescued a large number of boys from local sweatshops .
agents had lured them from india 's poorest regions , promising the children that they would be taken care of and paid well .
they were found hidden on the top floors of garment factories - held captive in filthy cramped rooms under lock and key .
they painstakingly spent hours applying crystals to garments .
many of the clothes end up being sold in shops in the uk .
ineffective these are places the authorities say are difficult to close down .
but swami agnivesh of the bonded liberation front says that hundreds of children are kept hidden from public view in the buildings of crammed alleyways .
" they are kept in the most appalling conditions and not enough is being done to help them , " he said .
india has laws in place to protect children and bans the use of young workers , but they remain pretty ineffective .
the united nations children 's ' fund says that the sheer volume of children engaged in work is living proof of the world 's failure to protect them .
that is the reason why the agency 's work is focused on building a protective environment which safeguards children from exploitation and abuse .
in tamil nadu local charities have helped pay off families ' debts so that at least some children can be released from the matchstick factories .
finally freed from the shackles of work , they now have some hope of reliving their childhood .
bu it is often a dream that is short-lived .
charity workers admit most of the children are likely to find themselves forced back into a life of bondage .

<p>
bbc news - mesmerising lure of hdtv british broadcasting corporation home accessibility links skip to content skip to local navigation skip to bbc.co.uk navigation skip to bbc.co.uk search help accessibility help bbc news updated every minute of every day one-minute world news news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk business health science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog bbc world service page last updated at 08:57 gmt , tuesday , 13 june 2006 09:57 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version mesmerising lure of hdtv hdtv , with its promise of sharper images and brighter colours , can be mesmerising , as the bbc 's martin shankleman found out .
q & a : high-definition tv one of the main effects of hallucinogenic drugs , i recall reading in my psychology studies , is a heightened sense of reality , which can make even the most mundane sights appear gripping .
i remember stories of students obsessively watching tomato soup come to the boil in a saucepan because they admired the swirl of bubbles .
having spent just one week with a hdtv system , i feel it has the same potential .
it can render even the most banal sights riveting .
since my high-definition system was installed , i have found myself studying the saliva strands inside a tortoise 's mouth and the nasty rash around sven-goran eriksson 's neck .
it has even got me examining robbie williams ' bloodshot eyes and wondering if he is getting enough sleep .
take me breath away the level of detail achieved by hd can be remarkable .
sky claims the picture quality is four times better than conventional sets .
hdtv in europe commercial hdtv services began with belgian channel euro180 in 2004 telewest launched the uk 's first hdtv service in march 2006 .
bbc and sky began hdtv transmissions in may 2006 bbc to have 100 % hd programmes by 2010 that means greater clarity in the images , best illustrated on nature programmes such as planet earth .
when the camera films a flock of migrating birds , it seems possible to focus on each individual member of the group .
a shot of the angel waterfalls in venezuela is breathtaking , as hd reveals how the water glistens as it tumbles over the mountain edge .
the range of colours is impressive as well .
hd produces subtle shades i am not used to seeing on tv .
this was best demonstrated on an artsworld documentary on impressionism , which revealed monet 's poppies has richer , deeper reds than i had seen before .
archive footage of jimi hendrix reveals the sumptuous maroon of his jacket .
i want my hdtv there are drawbacks though .
traditional programmes , and that is just about every existing show , can seem slightly flat .
the nature series planet earth is among the bbc 's first hd shows the picture lacks crispness and the colour seems washed in a yellow tint .
one explanation is that the hd system is so sophisticated that it exposes the flaws in programmes shot in the traditional 625 format .
in other words , the image is spread too thinly over the screen .
anyone who has watched football on a large screen in a pub will be only too familiar with the problem .
the problem is made worse by the fact that there is a dearth of hd programming available .
sky notionally offers 10 hd channels , but much of the programming is patchy and intermittent .
costs are high as well .
for a sky system , viewers need a new hd digibox , which costs £ 299 , and your tv set will probably need replacing , which could cost you at least £ 800 .
bookmark with : delicious digg reddit facebook stumbleupon what are these ?
e-mail this to a friend printable version see also hd tv buyers ' guide 28 jun 10 -pipe- click the low-down on high-definition 09 jun 06 -pipe- click q & a : high-definition tv 09 may 06 -pipe- entertainment high-definition tv : your views 27 may 06 -pipe- entertainment confusion over high-definition tv 21 mar 05 -pipe- technology related bbc links bbc high definition related internet links sky hd the bbc is not responsible for the content of external internet sites top technology stories us lifts lid on wikileaks probe bing gains market share in search ' virtual human ' makes xbox debut most popular stories now shared read watched / listened jellyfish attack destroys salmon who needs gigabit broadband ?
most popular now , in detail shared read watched / listened several injured in istanbul blast what was jon stewart 's rally in washington all about ?

please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets -lrb- css -rrb- if you are able to do so .

q & a : high-definition tv one of the main effects of hallucinogenic drugs , i recall reading in my psychology studies , is a heightened sense of reality , which can make even the most mundane sights appear gripping .
i remember stories of students obsessively watching tomato soup come to the boil in a saucepan because they admired the swirl of bubbles .
having spent just one week with a hdtv system , i feel it has the same potential .
it can render even the most banal sights riveting .
since my high-definition system was installed , i have found myself studying the saliva strands inside a tortoise 's mouth and the nasty rash around sven-goran eriksson 's neck .
it has even got me examining robbie williams ' bloodshot eyes and wondering if he is getting enough sleep .
take me breath away the level of detail achieved by hd can be remarkable .
sky claims the picture quality is four times better than conventional sets .
hdtv in europe commercial hdtv services began with belgian channel euro180 in 2004 telewest launched the uk 's first hdtv service in march 2006 .
bbc and sky began hdtv transmissions in may 2006 bbc to have 100 % hd programmes by 2010 that means greater clarity in the images , best illustrated on nature programmes such as planet earth .
when the camera films a flock of migrating birds , it seems possible to focus on each individual member of the group .
a shot of the angel waterfalls in venezuela is breathtaking , as hd reveals how the water glistens as it tumbles over the mountain edge .
the range of colours is impressive as well .
hd produces subtle shades i am not used to seeing on tv .
this was best demonstrated on an artsworld documentary on impressionism , which revealed monet 's poppies has richer , deeper reds than i had seen before .
archive footage of jimi hendrix reveals the sumptuous maroon of his jacket .
i want my hdtv there are drawbacks though .
traditional programmes , and that is just about every existing show , can seem slightly flat .
the nature series planet earth is among the bbc 's first hd shows the picture lacks crispness and the colour seems washed in a yellow tint .
one explanation is that the hd system is so sophisticated that it exposes the flaws in programmes shot in the traditional 625 format .
in other words , the image is spread too thinly over the screen .
anyone who has watched football on a large screen in a pub will be only too familiar with the problem .
the problem is made worse by the fact that there is a dearth of hd programming available .
sky notionally offers 10 hd channels , but much of the programming is patchy and intermittent .
costs are high as well .
for a sky system , viewers need a new hd digibox , which costs £ 299 , and your tv set will probably need replacing , which could cost you at least £ 800 .

q & a : high-definition tv one of the main effects of hallucinogenic drugs , i recall reading in my psychology studies , is a heightened sense of reality , which can make even the most mundane sights appear gripping .

bbc and sky began hdtv transmissions in may 2006 bbc to have 100 % hd programmes by 2010 that means greater clarity in the images , best illustrated on nature programmes such as planet earth .
when the camera films a flock of migrating birds , it seems possible to focus on each individual member of the group .
a shot of the angel waterfalls in venezuela is breathtaking , as hd reveals how the water glistens as it tumbles over the mountain edge .
the range of colours is impressive as well .

archive footage of jimi hendrix reveals the sumptuous maroon of his jacket .
i want my hdtv there are drawbacks though .
traditional programmes , and that is just about every existing show , can seem slightly flat .
the nature series planet earth is among the bbc 's first hd shows the picture lacks crispness and the colour seems washed in a yellow tint .
one explanation is that the hd system is so sophisticated that it exposes the flaws in programmes shot in the traditional 625 format .
in other words , the image is spread too thinly over the screen .
anyone who has watched football on a large screen in a pub will be only too familiar with the problem .
the problem is made worse by the fact that there is a dearth of hd programming available .
sky notionally offers 10 hd channels , but much of the programming is patchy and intermittent .
costs are high as well .
for a sky system , viewers need a new hd digibox , which costs £ 299 , and your tv set will probably need replacing , which could cost you at least £ 800 .

for a sky system , viewers need a new hd digibox , which costs £ 299 , and your tv set will probably need replacing , which could cost you at least £ 800 .

e-mail this to a friend printable version see also hd tv buyers ' guide 28 jun 10 -pipe- click the low-down on high-definition 09 jun 06 -pipe- click q & a : high-definition tv 09 may 06 -pipe- entertainment high-definition tv : your views 27 may 06 -pipe- entertainment confusion over high-definition tv 21 mar 05 -pipe- technology related bbc links bbc high definition related internet links sky hd the bbc is not responsible for the content of external internet sites top technology stories apple admits iphone signal fault russian freighter docks in space google moves into travel market most popular stories now shared read watched / listened snake bursts after gobbling gator untidy beds may keep us healthy one-minute world news arab culture explored at bluecoat earth 's gravity pictured in ' hd ' most popular now , in detail shared read watched / listened ex-eating champion arrested in us bp oil spill costs pass $ 3bn mark komorowski set for polish victory india strike over petrol prices snake bursts after gobbling gator sumo wrestler fired over gambling apple admits iphone signal fault obama backs giant solar project ss great britain : from seabed to national treasure former bosnian president in court most popular now , in detail shared read watched / listened protests at cliff viewing platform launch boy celebrates his return to cuba one-minute world news neil gaiman on comics and success japan may pick robots over immigrants queen dedicates stone to canada museum obama offers cameron ride to g20 cargo freighter docks with iss thousands celebrate at london pride china reimposes curfew in urumqi most popular now , in detail features , views , analysis promoting ' love ' music video builds unity in protest-hit thai capital mixed legacy how mohammed fadlallah was admired and reviled soul searching missionary lives and theological divides in malawi most popular now most popular now -pipe- 58,586 people are reading stories on the site right now . this page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets -lrb- css -rrb- enabled .
while you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser , you will not be able to get the full visual experience .

<p>
bbc news - mesmerising lure of hdtv british broadcasting corporation home accessibility links mobile version skip to content skip to local navigation skip to bbc.co.uk navigation skip to bbc.co.uk search help accessibility help bbc news updated every minute of every day one-minute world news news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk business health science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog bbc world service page last updated at 08:57 gmt , tuesday , 13 june 2006 09:57 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version mesmerising lure of hdtv hdtv , with its promise of sharper images and brighter colours , can be mesmerising , as the bbc 's martin shankleman found out .
q & a : high-definition tv one of the main effects of hallucinogenic drugs , i recall reading in my psychology studies , is a heightened sense of reality , which can make even the most mundane sights appear gripping .
i remember stories of students obsessively watching tomato soup come to the boil in a saucepan because they admired the swirl of bubbles .
having spent just one week with a hdtv system , i feel it has the same potential .
it can render even the most banal sights riveting .
since my high-definition system was installed , i have found myself studying the saliva strands inside a tortoise 's mouth and the nasty rash around sven-goran eriksson 's neck .
it has even got me examining robbie williams ' bloodshot eyes and wondering if he is getting enough sleep .
take me breath away the level of detail achieved by hd can be remarkable .
sky claims the picture quality is four times better than conventional sets .
hdtv in europe commercial hdtv services began with belgian channel euro180 in 2004 telewest launched the uk 's first hdtv service in march 2006 .
bbc and sky began hdtv transmissions in may 2006 bbc to have 100 % hd programmes by 2010 that means greater clarity in the images , best illustrated on nature programmes such as planet earth .
when the camera films a flock of migrating birds , it seems possible to focus on each individual member of the group .
a shot of the angel waterfalls in venezuela is breathtaking , as hd reveals how the water glistens as it tumbles over the mountain edge .
the range of colours is impressive as well .
hd produces subtle shades i am not used to seeing on tv .
this was best demonstrated on an artsworld documentary on impressionism , which revealed monet 's poppies has richer , deeper reds than i had seen before .
archive footage of jimi hendrix reveals the sumptuous maroon of his jacket .
i want my hdtv there are drawbacks though .
traditional programmes , and that is just about every existing show , can seem slightly flat .
the nature series planet earth is among the bbc 's first hd shows the picture lacks crispness and the colour seems washed in a yellow tint .
one explanation is that the hd system is so sophisticated that it exposes the flaws in programmes shot in the traditional 625 format .
in other words , the image is spread too thinly over the screen .
anyone who has watched football on a large screen in a pub will be only too familiar with the problem .
the problem is made worse by the fact that there is a dearth of hd programming available .
sky notionally offers 10 hd channels , but much of the programming is patchy and intermittent .
costs are high as well .
for a sky system , viewers need a new hd digibox , which costs £ 299 , and your tv set will probably need replacing , which could cost you at least £ 800 .
bookmark with : delicious digg reddit facebook stumbleupon what are these ?
e-mail this to a friend printable version see also hd tv buyers ' guide 28 jun 10 -pipe- click the low-down on high-definition 09 jun 06 -pipe- click q & a : high-definition tv 09 may 06 -pipe- entertainment high-definition tv : your views 27 may 06 -pipe- entertainment confusion over high-definition tv 21 mar 05 -pipe- technology related bbc links bbc high definition related internet links sky hd the bbc is not responsible for the content of external internet sites top technology stories us lifts lid on wikileaks probe bing gains market share in search ' virtual human ' makes xbox debut most popular stories now shared read watched / listened nigeria country profile most popular now , in detail shared read watched / listened iran tv airs ' confession ' from woman facing stoning man grows pea plant inside lung meteor spectacle ' set to dazzle ' brazil to record ufo sightings relic of ' original earth ' exposed dying girl photographs criticised pakistani president in flood zone met officers face assault charges market trading : how hard can it be ?
deadly fires rage on in portugal most popular now , in detail shared read watched / listened woman starts fight over chicken nuggets stinging jellyfish invade spanish coast uk teenager finds fame in japan women dice with death on m6 full flash video on phones saudi women photograph their world how a tragedy unfolded in pakistan ' fake fishermen ' claiming oil spill compensation one-minute world news cameron pays tribute to beckham most popular now , in detail features , views , analysis planning an exit attacks by afghan soldiers pose nato problems sanction evasion ?

bbc and sky began hdtv transmissions in may 2006 bbc to have 100 % hd programmes by 2010 that means greater clarity in the images , best illustrated on nature programmes such as planet earth .

this was best demonstrated on an artsworld documentary on impressionism , which revealed monet 's poppies has richer , deeper reds than i had seen before .
archive footage of jimi hendrix reveals the sumptuous maroon of his jacket .

traditional programmes , and that is just about every existing show , can seem slightly flat .
the nature series planet earth is among the bbc 's first hd shows the picture lacks crispness and the colour seems washed in a yellow tint .
one explanation is that the hd system is so sophisticated that it exposes the flaws in programmes shot in the traditional 625 format .
in other words , the image is spread too thinly over the screen .
anyone who has watched football on a large screen in a pub will be only too familiar with the problem .
the problem is made worse by the fact that there is a dearth of hd programming available .
sky notionally offers 10 hd channels , but much of the programming is patchy and intermittent .
costs are high as well .
for a sky system , viewers need a new hd digibox , which costs £ 299 , and your tv set will probably need replacing , which could cost you at least £ 800 .

this page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets -lrb- css -rrb- enabled .
while you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser , you will not be able to get the full visual experience .
please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets -lrb- css -rrb- if you are able to do so .
<p>
bbc news - mesmerising lure of hdtv british broadcasting corporation home accessibility links skip to content skip to local navigation skip to bbc.co.uk navigation skip to bbc.co.uk search help accessibility help bbc news updated every minute of every day one-minute world news news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk business health science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog bbc world service page last updated at 08:57 gmt , tuesday , 13 june 2006 09:57 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version mesmerising lure of hdtv hdtv , with its promise of sharper images and brighter colours , can be mesmerising , as the bbc 's martin shankleman found out .
q & a : high-definition tv one of the main effects of hallucinogenic drugs , i recall reading in my psychology studies , is a heightened sense of reality , which can make even the most mundane sights appear gripping .
i remember stories of students obsessively watching tomato soup come to the boil in a saucepan because they admired the swirl of bubbles .
having spent just one week with a hdtv system , i feel it has the same potential .
it can render even the most banal sights riveting .
since my high-definition system was installed , i have found myself studying the saliva strands inside a tortoise 's mouth and the nasty rash around sven-goran eriksson 's neck .
it has even got me examining robbie williams ' bloodshot eyes and wondering if he is getting enough sleep .
take me breath away the level of detail achieved by hd can be remarkable .
sky claims the picture quality is four times better than conventional sets .
hdtv in europe commercial hdtv services began with belgian channel euro180 in 2004 telewest launched the uk 's first hdtv service in march 2006 .
bbc and sky began hdtv transmissions in may 2006 bbc to have 100 % hd programmes by 2010 that means greater clarity in the images , best illustrated on nature programmes such as planet earth .
when the camera films a flock of migrating birds , it seems possible to focus on each individual member of the group .
a shot of the angel waterfalls in venezuela is breathtaking , as hd reveals how the water glistens as it tumbles over the mountain edge .
the range of colours is impressive as well .
hd produces subtle shades i am not used to seeing on tv .
this was best demonstrated on an artsworld documentary on impressionism , which revealed monet 's poppies has richer , deeper reds than i had seen before .
archive footage of jimi hendrix reveals the sumptuous maroon of his jacket .
i want my hdtv there are drawbacks though .
traditional programmes , and that is just about every existing show , can seem slightly flat .
the nature series planet earth is among the bbc 's first hd shows the picture lacks crispness and the colour seems washed in a yellow tint .
one explanation is that the hd system is so sophisticated that it exposes the flaws in programmes shot in the traditional 625 format .
in other words , the image is spread too thinly over the screen .
anyone who has watched football on a large screen in a pub will be only too familiar with the problem .
the problem is made worse by the fact that there is a dearth of hd programming available .
sky notionally offers 10 hd channels , but much of the programming is patchy and intermittent .
costs are high as well .
for a sky system , viewers need a new hd digibox , which costs £ 299 , and your tv set will probably need replacing , which could cost you at least £ 800 .
bookmark with : delicious digg reddit facebook stumbleupon what are these ?

hdtv in europe commercial hdtv services began with belgian channel euro180 in 2004 telewest launched the uk 's first hdtv service in march 2006 .
bbc and sky began hdtv transmissions in may 2006 bbc to have 100 % hd programmes by 2010 that means greater clarity in the images , best illustrated on nature programmes such as planet earth .

bbc news -pipe- technology -pipe- mesmerising lure of hdtv bbc news / technology graphics version bbc sport home news front page -pipe- africa -pipe- americas -pipe- asia-pacific -pipe- europe -pipe- middle east -pipe- south asia -pipe- uk -pipe- business -pipe- health -pipe- science & environment -pipe- technology -pipe- entertainment -pipe- also in the news -pipe- have your say -pipe- tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 08:57 gmt 09:57 uk mesmerising lure of hdtv hdtv , with its promise of sharper images and brighter colours , can be mesmerising , as the bbc 's martin shankleman found out .
q & a : high-definition tv one of the main effects of hallucinogenic drugs , i recall reading in my psychology studies , is a heightened sense of reality , which can make even the most mundane sights appear gripping .
i remember stories of students obsessively watching tomato soup come to the boil in a saucepan because they admired the swirl of bubbles .
having spent just one week with a hdtv system , i feel it has the same potential .
it can render even the most banal sights riveting .
since my high-definition system was installed , i have found myself studying the saliva strands inside a tortoise 's mouth and the nasty rash around sven-goran eriksson 's neck .
it has even got me examining robbie williams ' bloodshot eyes and wondering if he is getting enough sleep .
take me breath away the level of detail achieved by hd can be remarkable .
sky claims the picture quality is four times better than conventional sets .
hdtv in europe commercial hdtv services began with belgian channel euro180 in 2004 telewest launched the uk 's first hdtv service in march 2006 .
bbc and sky began hdtv transmissions in may 2006 bbc to have 100 % hd programmes by 2010 that means greater clarity in the images , best illustrated on nature programmes such as planet earth .
when the camera films a flock of migrating birds , it seems possible to focus on each individual member of the group .
a shot of the angel waterfalls in venezuela is breathtaking , as hd reveals how the water glistens as it tumbles over the mountain edge .
the range of colours is impressive as well .
hd produces subtle shades i am not used to seeing on tv .
this was best demonstrated on an artsworld documentary on impressionism , which revealed monet 's poppies has richer , deeper reds than i had seen before .
archive footage of jimi hendrix reveals the sumptuous maroon of his jacket .
i want my hdtv there are drawbacks though .
traditional programmes , and that is just about every existing show , can seem slightly flat .
the picture lacks crispness and the colour seems washed in a yellow tint .
one explanation is that the hd system is so sophisticated that it exposes the flaws in programmes shot in the traditional 625 format .
in other words , the image is spread too thinly over the screen .
anyone who has watched football on a large screen in a pub will be only too familiar with the problem .
the problem is made worse by the fact that there is a dearth of hd programming available .
sky notionally offers 10 hd channels , but much of the programming is patchy and intermittent .
costs are high as well .
for a sky system , viewers need a new hd digibox , which costs £ 299 , and your tv set will probably need replacing , which could cost you at least £ 800 .

<p>
bbc news -pipe- in depth -pipe- uk troops face worsening violence home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk business health science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 09:02 gmt 10:02 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version uk troops face worsening violence by alistair leithead bbc news , kabul the uk mission aims to bring security to the region the british mission to southern afghanistan was always going to be a difficult one , and military commanders here knew it would be just a matter of time before they suffered their first casualties .
the violence is worsening - in the last few weeks hundreds of people have died , and in the last two days there have been three significant battles in the south of the country .
every day the list of dead and injured increases , whether it be through the fighting , which has killed many afghan security personnel , or assassinations , roadside or suicide bombs .
and the south of the country has recently become the most dangerous .
quick guide afghanistan the canadian troops who have had responsibility for neighbouring kandahar province and commanding the whole south for the last few months have already lost nine people this year .
fighting ' peak ' as the british deployment began , senior officers were talking about a peak in fighting which would coincide with their arrival in helmand province .
they were worried by how long this would last and at what cost .
over the last four-and-a-half years there have been just a handful of us-led coalition troops on the ground in helmand and now there are thousands of soldiers with a mission to help the afghan authorities bring security to an area which is outside government control .
the british forces say that their presence is disturbing the status quo and will no doubt provoke a reaction from " people who just do n't want us to be there . "
this means criminals working in the illegal opium trade , local warlords and of course the taleban fighters , who appear to have been expanding in numbers over the past few months .
they are , however , still confident that people broadly support the coalition and the nato-led force and want the international community here - a big difference to the perception in iraq .
taleban influence but sources in helmand say there is not one district in the province which does not come under taleban influence and there are many areas where they are " in control . "
until people start to see things changing they are unlikely to stop supporting , or at the very least tolerating , the taleban fighters in their villages .
on the whole this means they openly move around and are a serious presence - enough to intimidate local people and for them to see the taleban as the real power rather than the government .
it takes little more than a pick-up truck full of armed taleban fighters driving down the main street to make that point .
but some villages are no-go areas for the police and army , particularly at night , and it is these the british forces are helping to secure - an incredibly difficult task .
it is easy enough to send the paras into an area with the afghan national army , clash with and drive out taleban militia , especially with the help of air-power , but then what ?
when the troops pull back to base , the taleban simply come back a few days later and it starts all over again .
the way the british troops are dealing with this is to set up a well protected compound in the town or village and help the police and army establish a base and maintain a small presence .
but helmand is four times the size of wales .
there are many towns and villages and with just a couple of thousand british troops supporting an inexperienced national army this constant expansion becomes difficult .
the whole point of the mission is to bring security and then almost immediately roll out development programmes , to show people that by supporting the government and the british forces their lives will improve .
the department for international development and the foreign and commonwealth office are working closely with the military to achieve this .
tens of millions of pounds have been made available .
but for the moment the security situation is just not good enough to roll out these programmes and until people start to see things changing they are unlikely to stop supporting , or at the very least tolerating , the taleban fighters in their villages .
public opinion the taleban government was born out of the religious scholars in southern afghanistan where their conservative views are normal and where , despite the barbaric rules , they did bring security .
that is what people most want at the moment .
a senior british military commander describes the mission in helmand as " to win the support of the floating voter " - the 80 % of people who want security and change and will support whoever can provide it .
at the moment the opinion polls show disappointment with what the democratic government has done or what all the billions of pounds of aid money has brought people .
there 's no doubt the british forces who will be working under nato have a great opportunity to make a difference .
but their success will depend on how long this " peak " of resistance goes on for , how much damage the taleban fighters can do and ultimately what losses the british and other international forces can take before public opinion at home starts to question and threaten their continued involvement in the mission .
e-mail this to a friend printable version uk troops in afghanistan latest news tributes paid to ' perfect marine ' prepare for more casualties - pm top army bomb squad officer quits ministers ' united ' on afghanistan beckham visits ' brave ' uk troops uk troops to go under us command features and analysis medal honour a full list of those awarded medals for bravery in afghanistan and iraq in 2009 combating ieds in afghanistan uk troops to come into us command bearing fruit sangin ' most dangerous for troops ' afghan mission ' has gone well ' soldier ' threw back hand grenade ' background q & a : british troops in afghanistan in depth : taliban conflict fatalities british military fatalities in afghanistan interactive graphic : uk military deaths broken down by age , date , rank and cause in video soldier throws back grenade sky drone ' spots ' taliban bombs uk troops deal with roadside bomb top stories now us chief in afghan civilian vow turkey and israel in secret talks toyota warning on engine faults most popular stories now most shared most read untidy beds may keep us healthy most popular now , in detail most shared most read japan marks atom bomb anniversary italy on the brink of new nuclear era the moon ' too dry to have life ' aziz says west misjudged saddam al-qaeda in pakistan ' top threat ' spreading pakistan floods hit 4m bp cements damaged gulf oil well why have the northern lights moved south ?
