bbc news -pipe- in depth -pipe- uk troops face worsening violence home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk business health science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 09:02 gmt 10:02 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version uk troops face worsening violence by alistair leithead bbc news , kabul the uk mission aims to bring security to the region the british mission to southern afghanistan was always going to be a difficult one , and military commanders here knew it would be just a matter of time before they suffered their first casualties .
the violence is worsening - in the last few weeks hundreds of people have died , and in the last two days there have been three significant battles in the south of the country .
every day the list of dead and injured increases , whether it be through the fighting , which has killed many afghan security personnel , or assassinations , roadside or suicide bombs .
and the south of the country has recently become the most dangerous .
quick guide afghanistan the canadian troops who have had responsibility for neighbouring kandahar province and commanding the whole south for the last few months have already lost nine people this year .
fighting ' peak ' as the british deployment began , senior officers were talking about a peak in fighting which would coincide with their arrival in helmand province .
they were worried by how long this would last and at what cost .
over the last four-and-a-half years there have been just a handful of us-led coalition troops on the ground in helmand and now there are thousands of soldiers with a mission to help the afghan authorities bring security to an area which is outside government control .
the british forces say that their presence is disturbing the status quo and will no doubt provoke a reaction from " people who just do n't want us to be there . "
this means criminals working in the illegal opium trade , local warlords and of course the taleban fighters , who appear to have been expanding in numbers over the past few months .
they are , however , still confident that people broadly support the coalition and the nato-led force and want the international community here - a big difference to the perception in iraq .
taleban influence but sources in helmand say there is not one district in the province which does not come under taleban influence and there are many areas where they are " in control . "
until people start to see things changing they are unlikely to stop supporting , or at the very least tolerating , the taleban fighters in their villages .
on the whole this means they openly move around and are a serious presence - enough to intimidate local people and for them to see the taleban as the real power rather than the government .
it takes little more than a pick-up truck full of armed taleban fighters driving down the main street to make that point .
but some villages are no-go areas for the police and army , particularly at night , and it is these the british forces are helping to secure - an incredibly difficult task .
it is easy enough to send the paras into an area with the afghan national army , clash with and drive out taleban militia , especially with the help of air-power , but then what ?
when the troops pull back to base , the taleban simply come back a few days later and it starts all over again .
the way the british troops are dealing with this is to set up a well protected compound in the town or village and help the police and army establish a base and maintain a small presence .
but helmand is four times the size of wales .
there are many towns and villages and with just a couple of thousand british troops supporting an inexperienced national army this constant expansion becomes difficult .
the whole point of the mission is to bring security and then almost immediately roll out development programmes , to show people that by supporting the government and the british forces their lives will improve .
the department for international development and the foreign and commonwealth office are working closely with the military to achieve this .
tens of millions of pounds have been made available .
but for the moment the security situation is just not good enough to roll out these programmes and until people start to see things changing they are unlikely to stop supporting , or at the very least tolerating , the taleban fighters in their villages .
public opinion the taleban government was born out of the religious scholars in southern afghanistan where their conservative views are normal and where , despite the barbaric rules , they did bring security .
that is what people most want at the moment .
a senior british military commander describes the mission in helmand as " to win the support of the floating voter " - the 80 % of people who want security and change and will support whoever can provide it .
at the moment the opinion polls show disappointment with what the democratic government has done or what all the billions of pounds of aid money has brought people .
there 's no doubt the british forces who will be working under nato have a great opportunity to make a difference .
but their success will depend on how long this " peak " of resistance goes on for , how much damage the taleban fighters can do and ultimately what losses the british and other international forces can take before public opinion at home starts to question and threaten their continued involvement in the mission .
e-mail this to a friend printable version uk troops in afghanistan latest news top army bomb squad officer quits ministers ' united ' on afghanistan beckham visits ' brave ' uk troops dead british marine named by mod uk troops to go under us command features and analysis medal honour a full list of those awarded medals for bravery in afghanistan and iraq in 2009 combating ieds in afghanistan uk troops to come into us command bearing fruit sangin ' most dangerous for troops ' afghan mission ' has gone well ' soldier ' threw back hand grenade ' background q & a : british troops in afghanistan in depth : taliban conflict fatalities british military fatalities in afghanistan interactive graphic : uk military deaths broken down by age , date , rank and cause in video soldier throws back grenade sky drone ' spots ' taliban bombs uk troops deal with roadside bomb top stories now uk coalition in first cabinet meeting thai army ' to seal off protests ' venezuelan gas platform ' sinks ' most popular stories now most shared most read e-mail error ends up on road sign cuba timeline setting the memory of holocaust victims in stone condoms ' too big ' for indian men us sculptor louise bourgeois dies most popular now , in detail most shared most read israel to free flotilla activists bp prepares new bid to curb spill ex-us vp al gore splits from wife us hails al-qaeda chief 's ' death ' doubt cast on israel raid account ' honey traps ' target russian dissidents israeli raid : what went wrong ?

horst , why ?

bbc news -pipe- uk -pipe- scotland -pipe- south of scotland -pipe- forest turbine inquiry under way bbc news / south of scotland graphics version bbc sport home news front page -pipe- africa -pipe- americas -pipe- asia-pacific -pipe- europe -pipe- middle east -pipe- south asia -pipe- uk -pipe- business -pipe- health -pipe- science & environment -pipe- technology -pipe- entertainment -pipe- also in the news -pipe- have your say -pipe- uk contents : england -pipe- northern ireland -pipe- scotland -pipe- wales -pipe- uk politics -pipe- education -pipe- magazine tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 09:10 gmt 10:10 uk forest turbine inquiry under way a public inquiry is starting in moffat into plans for a wind farm development in a dumfriesshire woodland .
it will examine proposals by scottish power to construct 71 turbines at harestanes heights in ae forest .
the hearing was organised by the scottish executive after the local council tabled an objection .
opponents claim the development would have a significant visual impact but developers say the scheme has been reduced in response to public concerns .
the inquiry is expected to last a total of three weeks before being adjourned until september .
it will re-open to consider the potential cumulative impact of the local development and the proposed clyde wind farm between biggar and moffat .
e-mail this to a friend related to this story : objection to revised turbine plan -lrb- 03 may 06 -pipe- scotland -rrb- summit studies wind farm inquiry -lrb- 20 feb 06 -pipe- scotland -rrb- residents air views on wind farms -lrb- 12 dec 05 -pipe- scotland -rrb- related internet links wind power scottish executive scottish power the bbc is not responsible for the content of external internet sites search bbc news : news front page -pipe- africa -pipe- americas -pipe- asia-pacific -pipe- europe -pipe- middle east -pipe- south asia -pipe- uk -pipe- business -pipe- health -pipe- science & environment -pipe- technology -pipe- entertainment -pipe- also in the news -pipe- have your say -pipe- uk contents : england -pipe- northern ireland -pipe- scotland -pipe- wales -pipe- uk politics -pipe- education -pipe- magazine newswatch -pipe- notes -pipe- contact us -pipe- about bbc news -pipe- profiles -pipe- history ^ back to top -pipe- bbc sport home -pipe- bbc homepage -pipe- contact us -pipe- help -pipe- ©

bbc news -pipe- uk -pipe- scotland -pipe- south of scotland -pipe- forest turbine inquiry under way home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk england northern ireland scotland wales uk politics education magazine business health science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 09:10 gmt 10:10 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version forest turbine inquiry under way the wind farm inquiry is due to last three weeks a public inquiry is starting in moffat into plans for a wind farm development in a dumfriesshire woodland .
it will examine proposals by scottish power to construct 71 turbines at harestanes heights in ae forest .
the hearing was organised by the scottish executive after the local council tabled an objection .
opponents claim the development would have a significant visual impact but developers say the scheme has been reduced in response to public concerns .
the inquiry is expected to last a total of three weeks before being adjourned until september .
it will re-open to consider the potential cumulative impact of the local development and the proposed clyde wind farm between biggar and moffat .

bbc news -pipe- uk -pipe- scotland -pipe- south of scotland -pipe- forest turbine inquiry under way home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk england northern ireland scotland wales uk politics education magazine business health science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 09:10 gmt 10:10 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version forest turbine inquiry under way the wind farm inquiry is due to last three weeks a public inquiry is starting in moffat into plans for a wind farm development in a dumfriesshire woodland .
it will examine proposals by scottish power to construct 71 turbines at harestanes heights in ae forest .
the hearing was organised by the scottish executive after the local council tabled an objection .
opponents claim the development would have a significant visual impact but developers say the scheme has been reduced in response to public concerns .
the inquiry is expected to last a total of three weeks before being adjourned until september .
it will re-open to consider the potential cumulative impact of the local development and the proposed clyde wind farm between biggar and moffat .

<p>
bbc news -pipe- uk -pipe- rubbish collection ' may be taxed ' bbc news / uk graphics version bbc sport home news front page -pipe- africa -pipe- americas -pipe- asia-pacific -pipe- europe -pipe- middle east -pipe- south asia -pipe- uk -pipe- business -pipe- health -pipe- science & environment -pipe- technology -pipe- entertainment -pipe- also in the news -pipe- have your say -pipe- uk contents : england -pipe- northern ireland -pipe- scotland -pipe- wales -pipe- uk politics -pipe- education -pipe- magazine tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 09:12 gmt 10:12 uk rubbish collection ' may be taxed ' charging householders for the amount of rubbish collected from their homes is being considered by the government as part of proposed council tax reforms .
sir michael lyons , who is conducting an inquiry into the future of the tax , told the times newspaper he was looking at environmental taxes .
these would be paid in addition to council tax to make the cost of services more visible .
the plan raises the prospect of waste being weighed by refuse collectors .
the proposals could allow councils to charge residents for the amount of waste they produce , and other possibilities include charging less to greener households and those who separate their waste .
sir michael told the paper : " i am clear that if people want more services , want to tackle difficult problems like congestion , environmental sustainability and water quality ... you ca n't just tackle those problems and say you do n't want to pay more tax . "
sir michael also said he was studying other european countries which already operate charges for waste that range between 25p and 50p a kilo .
increased bills local authorities are currently trying to hit ambitious government targets for recycling household waste .
there have been persistent claims that sir michael planned to increase council tax bills for householders who improved their homes with extensions , or for those with a picturesque view or bigger gardens .
earlier this year , he confirmed plans were being considered that would see the wealthiest homeowners make a " bigger contribution " .
sir michael was commissioned by deputy prime minister john prescott and chancellor gordon brown in july 2004 to undertake an independent inquiry into local government funding .
his remit was extended last september to include the role of town halls .
a spokesman for the department for communities and local government said : " sir michael will be giving his final report to ministers at the end of the year and ministers will consider all his proposals . "
and dr michael warhurst , a senior waste and resources campaigner for friends of the earth , told bbc news : " as long as people are given a really good recycling service , then the idea of charging them on the basis of the waste left behind , rather than just charging everything through council tax , we think is a very effective method of both boosting recycling but also encouraging people to really try to avoid generating so much waste in the first place . "
e-mail this to a friend related to this story : council tax -lrb- new valuation lists for england -rrb- bill -lrb- 07 nov 05 -pipe- bbc parliament -rrb- revaluation ' would hit millions ' -lrb- 15 dec 05 -pipe- uk politics -rrb- devolution call on council review -lrb- 30 mar 06 -pipe- uk politics -rrb- related internet links action network the times department for communities and local government the bbc is not responsible for the content of external internet sites search bbc news : news front page -pipe- africa -pipe- americas -pipe- asia-pacific -pipe- europe -pipe- middle east -pipe- south asia -pipe- uk -pipe- business -pipe- health -pipe- science & environment -pipe- technology -pipe- entertainment -pipe- also in the news -pipe- have your say -pipe- uk contents : england -pipe- northern ireland -pipe- scotland -pipe- wales -pipe- uk politics -pipe- education -pipe- magazine newswatch -pipe- notes -pipe- contact us -pipe- about bbc news -pipe- profiles -pipe- history ^ back to top -pipe- bbc sport home -pipe- bbc homepage -pipe- contact us -pipe- help -pipe- ©

"

<p>
bbc news -pipe- uk -pipe- rubbish collection ' may be taxed ' home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk england northern ireland scotland wales uk politics education magazine business health science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 09:12 gmt 10:12 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version rubbish collection ' may be taxed ' households could be charged for how much rubbish they produce charging householders for the amount of rubbish collected from their homes is being considered by the government as part of proposed council tax reforms .
sir michael lyons , who is conducting an inquiry into the future of the tax , told the times newspaper he was looking at environmental taxes .
these would be paid in addition to council tax to make the cost of services more visible .
the plan raises the prospect of waste being weighed by refuse collectors .
the proposals could allow councils to charge residents for the amount of waste they produce , and other possibilities include charging less to greener households and those who separate their waste .
sir michael told the paper : " i am clear that if people want more services , want to tackle difficult problems like congestion , environmental sustainability and water quality ... you ca n't just tackle those problems and say you do n't want to pay more tax . "
sir michael also said he was studying other european countries which already operate charges for waste that range between 25p and 50p a kilo .
increased bills local authorities are currently trying to hit ambitious government targets for recycling household waste .
there have been persistent claims that sir michael planned to increase council tax bills for householders who improved their homes with extensions , or for those with a picturesque view or bigger gardens .
earlier this year , he confirmed plans were being considered that would see the wealthiest homeowners make a " bigger contribution " .
sir michael was commissioned by deputy prime minister john prescott and chancellor gordon brown in july 2004 to undertake an independent inquiry into local government funding .
his remit was extended last september to include the role of town halls .
a spokesman for the department for communities and local government said : " sir michael will be giving his final report to ministers at the end of the year and ministers will consider all his proposals . "
and dr michael warhurst , a senior waste and resources campaigner for friends of the earth , told bbc news : " as long as people are given a really good recycling service , then the idea of charging them on the basis of the waste left behind , rather than just charging everything through council tax , we think is a very effective method of both boosting recycling but also encouraging people to really try to avoid generating so much waste in the first place . "
e-mail this to a friend printable version bbc news : video and audio how waste is treated at a recycling plant see also council tax -lrb- new valuation lists for england -rrb- bill 07 nov 05 -pipe- bbc parliament revaluation ' would hit millions ' 15 dec 05 -pipe- uk politics devolution call on council review 30 mar 06 -pipe- uk politics related bbc links action network related internet links the times department for communities and local government the bbc is not responsible for the content of external internet sites top uk stories major manhunt for afghan soldier unemployment dips to 2.47 million pm condemns sympathy for moat most popular stories now most shared most read halal holidays in the sun most popular now , in detail most shared most read swede faces $ 1m speeding penalty peru battles killer vampire bats german economy sees ' record ' growth of 2.2 % woman in nectar card row banned from every sainsbury 's home computers discover rare star many stuck as travel firm folds france condemns officer in togo moscow ' hiding heatstroke cases ' canadians board tamil asylum boat fresh flood surge due in pakistan most popular now , in detail features , views , analysis planning an exit attacks by afghan soldiers pose nato problems sanction evasion ?

<p>
bbc news -pipe- europe -pipe- euro mps debate stem cell funding home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk business health science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog languages russian polish serbian turkish ukrainian more last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 09:20 gmt 10:20 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version euro mps debate stem cell funding by alix kroeger bbc european union reporter , strasbourg the cells are drawn from human embryos meps are debating whether to prolong eu funding for stem cell research , which could lead to treatments for conditions such as heart disease and alzheimer 's .
only a tiny proportion of eu science funding for 2007-13 will go to stem cell research , under current plans .
but it is a controversial issue , and catholic meps from new member states could bolster the ranks of opponents .
the cells are drawn from human embryos and can be used to duplicate different types of tissue .
critics say most stem cells are taken from embryos which have the potential to become human beings and that it is wrong to use them for experiments .
the european commission wants to keep the same policy - which funds some stem cell research but not the use of cloned stem cells - for the next six-year framework research programme .
however , there could be greater opposition now from meps from catholic countries like poland and slovakia , which joined the eu after the last research programme was decided .
only three countries , britain , sweden and belgium , allow research using cloned stem cells .
a survey by the european federation of neurological associations of 5,411 eu citizens found 83 % thought public funding should be used for human embyronic stem cell research .
the survey also found 84 % do not think patients are sufficiently involved in the debate on stem cell research .
e-mail this to a friend printable version inside europe latest news traffickers targeted in eu raids eu against palestinian state move eu cracks down on mobile services lisbon treaty hewitt on europe eu jobs race could be marathon eu leaders asked to pick a woman q & a : the lisbon treaty eu president : names in the frame timeline : the road to lisbon eu eyes bigger global role lisbon treaty : what they said uk and europe bnp in alliance with nationalists q & a : how uk adopts eu laws features european parliament guide what if the uk left the eu ?
a toast to europe 's diversity video on demand eu to pay ' fair share ' to help others tackle climate change what does an eu commissioner do ?
what does an mep do ?

bbc news -pipe- europe -pipe- euro mps debate stem cell funding home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk business health science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog languages russian albanian serbian turkish ukrainian more last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 09:20 gmt 10:20 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version euro mps debate stem cell funding by alix kroeger bbc european union reporter , strasbourg the cells are drawn from human embryos meps are debating whether to prolong eu funding for stem cell research , which could lead to treatments for conditions such as heart disease and alzheimer 's .
only a tiny proportion of eu science funding for 2007-13 will go to stem cell research , under current plans .
but it is a controversial issue , and catholic meps from new member states could bolster the ranks of opponents .
the cells are drawn from human embryos and can be used to duplicate different types of tissue .
critics say most stem cells are taken from embryos which have the potential to become human beings and that it is wrong to use them for experiments .
the european commission wants to keep the same policy - which funds some stem cell research but not the use of cloned stem cells - for the next six-year framework research programme .
however , there could be greater opposition now from meps from catholic countries like poland and slovakia , which joined the eu after the last research programme was decided .
only three countries , britain , sweden and belgium , allow research using cloned stem cells .
a survey by the european federation of neurological associations of 5,411 eu citizens found 83 % thought public funding should be used for human embyronic stem cell research .
the survey also found 84 % do not think patients are sufficiently involved in the debate on stem cell research .
e-mail this to a friend printable version inside europe latest news europe proposes new levy on banks italy joins euro austerity drive germany ' to extend trading ban ' eu says telecoms ' too fragmented ' lisbon treaty q & a : eu external action service q & a : the lisbon treaty uk and europe hague ' vindicated ' by euro crisis how will liberals influence foreign policy ?
q & a : how uk adopts eu laws features hewitt on europe will europeans accept a slimmed-down welfare state ?
what europe can learn from the us doubts surface over europe rescue eu commission : who 's who ?

text drive film to ' shock ' pupils most popular now , in detail most shared most read japan pm hatoyama ' to step down ' bp prepares new bid to curb spill israel to free flotilla activists ex-us vp al gore splits from wife us hails al-qaeda chief 's ' death ' homer named greatest tv character israeli raid : what went wrong ?
' first ' neanderthal tool evidence ' honey traps ' target russian dissidents doubt cast on israel raid account most popular now , in detail features , views , analysis one-sided can a jirga without rebel leaders bring afghanistan peace ?
horst , why ?

bbc news -pipe- europe -pipe- euro mps debate stem cell funding bbc news / europe graphics version bbc sport home news front page -pipe- africa -pipe- americas -pipe- asia-pacific -pipe- europe -pipe- middle east -pipe- south asia -pipe- uk -pipe- business -pipe- health -pipe- science & environment -pipe- technology -pipe- entertainment -pipe- also in the news -pipe- have your say -pipe- tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 09:20 gmt 10:20 uk euro mps debate stem cell funding by alix kroeger bbc european union reporter , strasbourg meps are debating whether to prolong eu funding for stem cell research , which could lead to treatments for conditions such as heart disease and alzheimer 's .

<p>
bbc news -pipe- health -pipe- pioneering eye operation in baby home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk business health medical notes science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 09:22 gmt 10:22 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version pioneering eye operation in baby the plastic implant is fitted into the cornea us doctors have successfully carried out the first artificial cornea implant operation on a british child .
seven-week-old aaron rai from windsor had the operation after his father found one of only two doctors in the world who do the procedure in babies .
professor james aquavella , who carried out the surgery at rochester eye institute in new york , said the two-hour operation went ' very well ' .
the team has done 19 such operations in children - all have been successful .
" with this prosthesis in place the quality of the vision should be good but what has to happen is the brain has to learn how to use that image . "
professor james aquavella aaron was born with an anterior segment development disorder in his right eye - which meant he could n't see out of the eye because the cornea , the transparent dome of tissue that covers the eye and focuses light , was opaque .
the operation to replace his cornea with a plastic prosthesis was carried out on monday .
aaron 's father surinder rai , found the us team willing to carry out the operation after british doctors decided the potential benefits of surgery did not outweigh the risks because aaron could still see out of one eye .
professor aquavella told the bbc website that they found no other problem with aaron 's eye and the operation went ahead as planned .
" we are very pleased .
with this prosthesis in place the quality of the vision should be good but what has to happen is the brain has to learn how to use that image . "
eye patch other operations by professor aquavella have been done in children aged four weeks to seven years - aaron is the second youngest child to be fitted with an artificial implant .
" the ideal case is to operate before two months of age , " he said and explained that if you operate early the brain can learn to process visual information properly .
" starting over the next few days the other eye will be patched for a few hours a day - the idea is to get him to use an eye that he has n't been using before . "
he added : " it will be years before we can assess definitively whether the operation has been successful because he has to be old enough to read out letters and answer questions but there are ways we can assess the eye in the meantime , for instance we can give the child objects of different sizes to play with . "
aaron was able to leave the hospital later the same day to spend the night with his parents in the hotel .
they plan to return to the uk at the weekend .
hoping for a breakthrough in the uk , transplants are done using corneas from donors but usually only in children who are blind in both eyes .
mr ken nischal , consultant ophthalmologist at great ormond street hospital for children , examined aaron before he went to the us .
he said : " we have a tremendous amount of experience in these children ; we have done 63 corneal grafts in babies . "
" i 'm supportive of the parents choice ; it was a difficult decision for them and i 'm hoping this is a breakthrough but i do n't have any scientific data to analyse .
" i feel apprehensive because we do n't have the data .
even if i had the experience with this -lsb- type of artificial implant -rsb- i would n't have done it in this child .
" we do n't know how long the material will last - it might not last longer than 10 years . "
he added that with one good eye , aaron would be able to lead a perfectly normal life .
ranjit rai , aaron 's mother , told the times she was initially " very worried " about the operation but was won over during a trip to the us to meet professor aquavella .
" we were very fortunate in that we were sufficiently focused and that our perseverance paid off so that we were able to identify an alternative way forward , " she said .
e-mail this to a friend printable version see also latest eye surgery looks to cells 20 dec 05 -pipe- england appeal for more eye tissue donors 07 apr 05 -pipe- southern counties artificial cornea project funded 19 aug 04 -pipe- england related internet links rochester eye institute great ormond street hospital the bbc is not responsible for the content of external internet sites top health stories stem cell method put to the test hospitals ' eyeing private market ' low vitamin d ' parkinson 's link ' most popular stories now most shared most read the ' future of money ' goes mobile most popular now , in detail most shared most read boy named hitler to stay in care mandela aide ' got campbell gems ' japan ship damage ' was terrorism ' pakistan 's flooding pushes south lockerbie bomber cancer ' no fake ' dense wildfire smog grips moscow japan marks atom bomb anniversary wyclef jean files election papers nz judge orders ' odd ' name change rbs half-year profits hit £ 1.1bn most popular now , in detail features , views , analysis planning an exit attacks by afghan soldiers pose nato problems sanction evasion ?

ranjit rai , aaron 's mother , told the times she was initially " very worried " about the operation but was won over during a trip to the us to meet professor aquavella .
" we were very fortunate in that we were sufficiently focused and that our perseverance paid off so that we were able to identify an alternative way forward , " she said .
e-mail this to a friend printable version see also latest eye surgery looks to cells 20 dec 05 -pipe- england appeal for more eye tissue donors 07 apr 05 -pipe- southern counties artificial cornea project funded 19 aug 04 -pipe- england related internet links rochester eye institute great ormond street hospital the bbc is not responsible for the content of external internet sites top health stories lax parents ' fuel binge drinking ' donors in israel get op priority experts crack cancer ' gene code ' most popular stories now most shared most read experts crack cancer ' gene code ' food hormone link to alzheimer 's major holiday airline goes bust vietnam to buy russian submarines fifty needles found in brazil boy most popular now , in detail most shared most read fifty needles found in brazil boy experts crack cancer ' gene code ' club promotes polygamy in indonesia indian woman wrestler overcomes fear factor boys aged 10 facing rape charges climate talks resuming after row bbc found zeppelin ' unconvincing ' major holiday airline goes bust credit suisse to pay $ 536m fine mexico police severed heads found most popular now , in detail features , views , analysis fear factor glamorous woman taking indian wrestling by storm romania 's revolt how support for a pastor turned into an uprising polygamy club controversial new group divides indonesian opinion most popular now most popular now -pipe- 19,600 people are reading stories on the site right now .

<p>
bbc news -pipe- health -pipe- pioneering eye operation in baby home news sport radio tv weather languages low graphics -pipe- accessibility help one-minute world news news services your news when you want it news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk business health medical notes science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog last updated : tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 09:22 gmt 10:22 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version pioneering eye operation in baby the plastic implant is fitted into the cornea us doctors have successfully carried out the first artificial cornea implant operation on a british child .
seven-week-old aaron rai from windsor had the operation after his father found one of only two doctors in the world who do the procedure in babies .
professor james aquavella , who carried out the surgery at rochester eye institute in new york , said the two-hour operation went ' very well ' .
the team has done 19 such operations in children - all have been successful .
" with this prosthesis in place the quality of the vision should be good but what has to happen is the brain has to learn how to use that image . "
professor james aquavella aaron was born with an anterior segment development disorder in his right eye - which meant he could n't see out of the eye because the cornea , the transparent dome of tissue that covers the eye and focuses light , was opaque .
the operation to replace his cornea with a plastic prosthesis was carried out on monday .
aaron 's father surinder rai , found the us team willing to carry out the operation after british doctors decided the potential benefits of surgery did not outweigh the risks because aaron could still see out of one eye .
professor aquavella told the bbc website that they found no other problem with aaron 's eye and the operation went ahead as planned .
" we are very pleased .
with this prosthesis in place the quality of the vision should be good but what has to happen is the brain has to learn how to use that image . "
eye patch other operations by professor aquavella have been done in children aged four weeks to seven years - aaron is the second youngest child to be fitted with an artificial implant .
" the ideal case is to operate before two months of age , " he said and explained that if you operate early the brain can learn to process visual information properly .
" starting over the next few days the other eye will be patched for a few hours a day - the idea is to get him to use an eye that he has n't been using before . "
he added : " it will be years before we can assess definitively whether the operation has been successful because he has to be old enough to read out letters and answer questions but there are ways we can assess the eye in the meantime , for instance we can give the child objects of different sizes to play with . "
aaron was able to leave the hospital later the same day to spend the night with his parents in the hotel .
they plan to return to the uk at the weekend .
hoping for a breakthrough in the uk , transplants are done using corneas from donors but usually only in children who are blind in both eyes .
mr ken nischal , consultant ophthalmologist at great ormond street hospital for children , examined aaron before he went to the us .
he said : " we have a tremendous amount of experience in these children ; we have done 63 corneal grafts in babies . "
" i 'm supportive of the parents choice ; it was a difficult decision for them and i 'm hoping this is a breakthrough but i do n't have any scientific data to analyse .
" i feel apprehensive because we do n't have the data .
even if i had the experience with this -lsb- type of artificial implant -rsb- i would n't have done it in this child .
" we do n't know how long the material will last - it might not last longer than 10 years . "
he added that with one good eye , aaron would be able to lead a perfectly normal life .
ranjit rai , aaron 's mother , told the times she was initially " very worried " about the operation but was won over during a trip to the us to meet professor aquavella .
" we were very fortunate in that we were sufficiently focused and that our perseverance paid off so that we were able to identify an alternative way forward , " she said .

"
aaron was able to leave the hospital later the same day to spend the night with his parents in the hotel .
they plan to return to the uk at the weekend .
hoping for a breakthrough in the uk , transplants are done using corneas from donors but usually only in children who are blind in both eyes .
mr ken nischal , consultant ophthalmologist at great ormond street hospital for children , examined aaron before he went to the us .
he said : " we have a tremendous amount of experience in these children ; we have done 63 corneal grafts in babies . "
" i 'm supportive of the parents choice ; it was a difficult decision for them and i 'm hoping this is a breakthrough but i do n't have any scientific data to analyse .
" i feel apprehensive because we do n't have the data .
even if i had the experience with this -lsb- type of artificial implant -rsb- i would n't have done it in this child .
" we do n't know how long the material will last - it might not last longer than 10 years . "
he added that with one good eye , aaron would be able to lead a perfectly normal life .
ranjit rai , aaron 's mother , told the times she was initially " very worried " about the operation but was won over during a trip to the us to meet professor aquavella .
" we were very fortunate in that we were sufficiently focused and that our perseverance paid off so that we were able to identify an alternative way forward , " she said .

mr ken nischal , consultant ophthalmologist at great ormond street hospital for children , examined aaron before he went to the us .
he said : " we have a tremendous amount of experience in these children ; we have done 63 corneal grafts in babies . "
" i 'm supportive of the parents choice ; it was a difficult decision for them and i 'm hoping this is a breakthrough but i do n't have any scientific data to analyse .
" i feel apprehensive because we do n't have the data .
even if i had the experience with this -lsb- type of artificial implant -rsb- i would n't have done it in this child .
" we do n't know how long the material will last - it might not last longer than 10 years . "
he added that with one good eye , aaron would be able to lead a perfectly normal life .
ranjit rai , aaron 's mother , told the times she was initially " very worried " about the operation but was won over during a trip to the us to meet professor aquavella .
" we were very fortunate in that we were sufficiently focused and that our perseverance paid off so that we were able to identify an alternative way forward , " she said .
e-mail this to a friend printable version see also latest eye surgery looks to cells 20 dec 05 -pipe- england appeal for more eye tissue donors 07 apr 05 -pipe- southern counties artificial cornea project funded 19 aug 04 -pipe- england related internet links rochester eye institute great ormond street hospital the bbc is not responsible for the content of external internet sites top health stories stem cell method put to the test hospitals ' eyeing private market ' low vitamin d ' parkinson 's link ' most popular stories now most shared most read the battle for berlin 's gardens inside castro 's revolutionary hideout most popular now , in detail most shared most read turkey groom kills wedding guests robbie williams weds ayda field rescue effort for china landslide couple murdered on pakistan trip mexico police hold own commander venezuela-colombia talks agreed hague test for campbell evidence eurosceptic swiss count their blessings iran lawyer in norway asylum bid world sauna event finalist dies most popular now , in detail features , views , analysis planning an exit attacks by afghan soldiers pose nato problems sanction evasion ?

<p>
bbc news -pipe- uk -pipe- wales -pipe- call for choice to ' die at home ' bbc news / wales graphics version bbc sport home news front page -pipe- africa -pipe- americas -pipe- asia-pacific -pipe- europe -pipe- middle east -pipe- south asia -pipe- uk -pipe- business -pipe- health -pipe- science & environment -pipe- technology -pipe- entertainment -pipe- also in the news -pipe- have your say -pipe- uk contents : england -pipe- northern ireland -pipe- scotland -pipe- wales -pipe- uk politics -pipe- magazine tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 09:30 gmt 10:30 uk call for choice to ' die at home ' more patients with terminal illnesses should be given the choice of dying at home , according to a cancer charity .
marie curie called on the welsh assembly government to put more money into palliative care outside hospitals .
the charity said the majority of patients would prefer to be allowed home for the final weeks of their life .
the assembly government said it was important the views and preferences of patients and their carers were taken into account .
marie curie has already helped more than 60 patients with terminal cancer in wales to fulfil their wish of dying at home .
and the assembly government has extended funding for the charity 's admission and discharge support scheme , launched in march 2005 , for another year .
' new way of thinking ' but the organisation said the majority of the 8,000 people who died of cancer in wales had died in hospital - even though many would rather be at home .
marie curie hospice manager viv cooper said research had found that for every £ 1 invested in care at home , £ 2 would be released to nhs wales .
ms cooper said : " our campaign is about convincing the welsh assembly government that the vast majority of people in wales say that if they were terminally ill , they would wish to die at home - and that , economically , it is the best option for the health service . "
the assembly government said " new ways of thinking " were needed in palliative care and welcomed the involvement of marie curie .
a spokesperson said they planned to improve the way terminally ill patients were " supported and managed " .
" an important part of good palliative care provision is ensuring that the views and preferences of patients and their carers are taken into account . "
e-mail this to a friend related to this story : new initiative for terminally ill -lrb- 09 jun 06 -pipe- tayside and central -rrb- calls for better care for dying -lrb- 10 jan 06 -pipe- uk politics -rrb- get inside your doctor 's head -lrb- 12 oct 05 -pipe- magazine -rrb- hospice funding ' must be boosted ' -lrb- 04 oct 05 -pipe- health -rrb- search bbc news : news front page -pipe- africa -pipe- americas -pipe- asia-pacific -pipe- europe -pipe- middle east -pipe- south asia -pipe- uk -pipe- business -pipe- health -pipe- science & environment -pipe- technology -pipe- entertainment -pipe- also in the news -pipe- have your say -pipe- uk contents : england -pipe- northern ireland -pipe- scotland -pipe- wales -pipe- uk politics -pipe- magazine newswatch -pipe- notes -pipe- contact us -pipe- about bbc news -pipe- profiles -pipe- history ^ back to top -pipe- bbc sport home -pipe- bbc homepage -pipe- contact us -pipe- help -pipe- ©

<p>
bbc news -pipe- uk -pipe- scotland -pipe- highlands and islands -pipe- broadband television for islands bbc news / highlands and islands graphics version bbc sport home news front page -pipe- africa -pipe- americas -pipe- asia-pacific -pipe- europe -pipe- middle east -pipe- south asia -pipe- uk -pipe- business -pipe- health -pipe- science & environment -pipe- technology -pipe- entertainment -pipe- also in the news -pipe- have your say -pipe- uk contents : england -pipe- northern ireland -pipe- scotland -pipe- wales -pipe- uk politics -pipe- education -pipe- magazine tuesday , 13 june 2006 , 09:34 gmt 10:34 uk broadband television for islands broadband technology is to be used to give islanders access to locally produced television programmes through their pcs .
western isles council , western isles enterprise and other project partners , have received funding from europe 's leader + initiative .
a pilot service will be run between 2006/07 to gauge the level interest from residents .
a website will provide a link to hebrides tv .
the project 's backers believe a wide range of local activity , events and local news could be filmed and made available online .
site content consultants will liaise with community groups and voluntary sector to identify and encourage content for the site .
last december , the scottish executive announced that a project which aimed to give every community in scotland access to broadband services had been completed .
over eight months some 378 remote and rural telephone exchanges - a third of the scottish total - have been upgraded .
the executive said the scheme would bring " far-reaching " business and educational benefits .
the project was part of the executive 's £ 24m broadband initiative , run in partnership with bt .

western isles council , western isles enterprise and other project partners , have received funding from europe 's leader + initiative .

the executive said the scheme would bring " far-reaching " business and educational benefits .
the project was part of the executive 's £ 24m broadband initiative , run in partnership with bt .
